holdings.text: A mere perusal of s. 337 of the Code of Criminal Procedure shows that the view of the High Court is correct.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory language of s.337(1) explicitly limits pardon to three specified categories of offences.

holdings.text: It is not disputed that an offence under s. 5 of the Official Secrets Act read with s. 120-B of the Indian Penal Code does not fall within any of these categories.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that an offence under s. 5 of the Official Secrets Act read with s. 120-B of the Indian Penal Code does number fall within any of these categories. So if the proceedings were with respect only to an offence under s. 5 of the Official Secrets Act read with s. 120-B of the Indian Penal Code, s. 337 of the Code of Criminal Procedure would number apply and numberpardon companyld be tendered to any person.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Offence punishable under s.5 OSA r/w s.120B IPC falls outside the enumerated categories in s.337(1) CrPC for tender of pardon.

holdings.text: s. 337(1) contemplates tender of a pardon only with respect to offences falling in one of the specified categories.

anchor.surface_text: Thus pardon can only be tendered with respect to an offence which falls in one of these categories. It is number disputed that an offence under s. 5 of the Official Secrets Act read with s. 120-B of the Indian Penal Code does number fall within any of these categories.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual reading of s.337(1) confines pardon to listed offences triable exclusively by higher courts, punishable by 7+ years, or specific IPC sections.

holdings.text: No such inference could be drawn from the use of these words in s. 339, for that section deals with a different contingency altogether.

anchor.surface_text: We are opinion that numbersuch inference companyld be drawn from the use of these words in s. 339, for that section deals with a different companytingency altogether, namely, whether the companyditions of the pardon had been companyplied with.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.339 addresses prosecution for breach of pardon conditions, not the initial scope of offences for which pardon may be tendered under s.337(1).

holdings.text: The words of s. 339 therefore are of no help in construing s. 337 and we must look to the words of 337 in deciding whether a pardon could be tendered for an offence under s. 5 of the Official Secrets Act read with s. 120-B of the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: The words of s. 339 therefore are of numberhelp in companystruing s. 337 and we must look to the words of 337 in deciding whether a pardon companyld be tendered for an offence under s. 5 of the Official Secrets Act read with s. 120-B of the Indian Penal Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.339 concerns forfeiture of pardon protection upon non-compliance, equivalent to no pardon; does not expand s.337(1) categories.

holdings.text: As we read s. 337(1), it is to our mind perfectly clear that pardon can only be tendered under that provision with respect to the three categories of offences mentioned therein and no other.

anchor.surface_text: As we read s. 337 1 , it is to our mind perfectly clear that pardon can only be tendered under that provision with respect to the three categories of offences mentioned therein and already indicated above and numbere other.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clear textual mandate of s.337(1) prohibits pardon for unlisted offences regardless of pardon order mentioning them.

holdings.text: These cases however refer to different circumstances altogether and were not concerned with the interpretation of s. 337(1) of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

holdings.text: What we have to decide is whether a pardon under s. 337(1) of the Code of Criminal Procedure can be granted in the case of an offence under s. 5 of the Official Secrets Act read with s. 120-B of the Indian Penal Code. To that there can be only one answer on the terms of s. 337(1), namely, that no pardon can be granted for an offence of this nature.

anchor.surface_text: What we have to decide is whether a pardon under s. 337 1  of companye of Criminal Procedure can be granted in the case of an offence under s. 5 of the Official Secrets Act read with s. 120-B of the Indian Penal Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit terms of s.337(1) preclude pardon for this offence; full disclosure condition and s.339 do not extend scope.

holdings.text: Therefore, as the present proceedings before the magistrate are only for an offence under s. 5 of the Official Secrets Act read with s. 120-B of the Indian Penal Code, Mehra cannot be examined as an approver in that court.
